com.gracenote.gnsdk
Class GnMic

java.lang.Object
  com.gracenote.gnsdk.GnMic
All Implemented Interfaces:
IGnAudioSource
public class GnMic
extends java.lang.Object
implements IGnAudioSource

The GnMic class manages the recording of audio from the device microphone and allows for simple plug-in of the audio source with GnMusicIdStream. This is a Gracenote helper delegate class to extract receive audio from a microphone. It can be used by GNSDK as an audio stream source that can be identified (GnMusicIdStream). For all helper delegate classes you can provide your own implementation, it just needs to implement the correct interface, in this case IGnAudioSource. If you do provide your own implementation Gracenote recommends starting with this implementation and altering as required; therefore the source is available on request.

Constructor Summary
GnMic()
          Initializes with default audio configuration, which is the first hardware-supported value found from the following sample rates supported by the SDK {8000, 11025, 16000, 22050, 24000, 32000, 44100, 48000} and favoring MONO over STEREO, 16-bit over 8-bit PCM.

Constructor Detail

GnMic

public GnMic()
Initializes with default audio configuration, which is the first hardware-supported value found from the following sample rates supported by the SDK {8000, 11025, 16000, 22050, 24000, 32000, 44100, 48000} and favoring MONO over STEREO, 16-bit over 8-bit PCM. Note that only 44100Hz sample rate, MONO audio channel configuration and 16-bit sample format are guaranteed to work on all devices.

GnMic

public GnMic(int samplesPerSecond,
             int bitsPerSamples,
             int numChannels)
Initializes with given audio configuration. If the requested audio configuration is not supported then a default supported audio configuration is used. If your application uses the audio configuration for any purpose ensure the actual audio configuration is read from the created GnMic object.

Parameters:
samplesPerSecond - sample rates supported by the SDK {8000, 11025, 16000, 22050, 24000, 32000, 44100, 48000}. Note that 44100Hz is currently the only sample rate that is guaranteed to work on all devices.
bitsPerSamples - 8 or 16 are the only supported values. Note that 16 bits per sample is currently the only sample format guaranteed to work on all devices.
numChannels - number of channels 1 corresponds to MONO, and any other value will default to STEREO. Note that only MONO is guaranteed to work on all devices. For example, Motorola and Samsung devices are not able to record in STEREO.
